elements.content: In our effort to seek for the “green” energetic coordination polymers (CPs), a versatile and multifunctional 1-amino-tetrazol-5-one ligand was synthesized and its complexes with a series of alkaline and earth alkaline metals were prepared and comprehensively characterized. A broad range of differently shaped 1D, 2D, and 3D supramolecular structures for the prepared energetic compounds were found, where each metal was bound in a specific and characteristic fashion. All prepared CPs show very good thermostability, with decomposition temperatures above 236 °C and remarkable insensitivity to mechanical impact and friction (impact sensitivity > 40 J, friction sensitivity > 360 N). In terms of detonation performance, our CPs were calculated to have detonation velocities in the range of 6.8–8.1 km·s–1 and detonation pressures in the range of 16.5–24.5 GPa. Upon their combustion, new materials show a range of characteristic flame colors (from yellow to blue), making these compounds as promising components for various “green” pyrotechnic formulations.
elements.clean_text: In our effort to seek for the "green" energetic coordination polymers (CPs), a versatile and multifunctional 1-amino-tetrazol-5-one ligand was synthesized and its complexes with a series of alkaline and earth alkaline metals were prepared and comprehensively characterized. A broad range of differently shaped 1D, 2D, and 3D supramolecular structures for the prepared energetic compounds were found, where each metal was bound in a specific and characteristic fashion. All prepared CPs show very good thermostability, with decomposition temperatures above 236 °C and remarkable insensitivity to mechanical impact and friction (impact sensitivity > 40 J, friction sensitivity > 360 N). In terms of detonation performance, our CPs were calculated to have detonation velocities in the range of 6.8-8.1 km⋅s-1 and detonation pressures in the range of 16.5-24.5 GPa. Upon their combustion, new materials show a range of characteristic flame colors (from yellow to blue), making these compounds as promising components for various "green" pyrotechnic formulations.

elements.content: A versatile and multifunctional nitrogen-rich 1-amino-tetrazol-5-one ligand was used for the preparation of new energetic materials containing alkaline and earth alkaline metals. These materials were found to have a broad range of structures, where for each type of metal a specific solid-state structure was formed. They were found to be thermostable and insensitive to impact and friction and showed specific emitted color upon their combustion, making them attractive potential components for pyrotechnic formulations.

They were found to be thermostable and insensitive to impact and friction and showed specific emitted color upon their combustion, making them attractive potential components for pyrotechnic formulations.

elements.content: Pyrotechnics have diverse applications in various fields, including the fireworks, safety matches, oxygen candles, explosive bolts and fasteners, components for automotive airbag inflators, mining, quarrying, and demolition. Many pyrotechnic compounds and formulations may contain various toxic substances, such as transition metal salts and complexes, perchlorate salts, and polychlorinated organic compounds. Also, upon deflagration and combustion of these pyrotechnics, some hazardous substances could be released in a form of smoke and gaseous products. Thus, it is highly desirable to develop “greener” (e.g., perchlorate-free) pyrotechnics in order to reduce a human exposure and environmental pollution.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Pyrotechnics have diverse applications in various fields, including the fireworks, safety matches, oxygen candles, explosive bolts and fasteners, components for automotive airbag inflators, mining, quarrying, and demolition. Many pyrotechnic compounds and formulations may contain various toxic substances, such as transition metal salts and complexes, perchlorate salts, and polychlorinated organic compounds. Also, upon deflagration and combustion of these pyrotechnics, some hazardous substances could be released in a form of smoke and gaseous products. Thus, it is highly desirable to develop "greener" (e.g., perchlorate-free) pyrotechnics in order to reduce a human exposure and environmental pollution.

elements.content: In recent years, extensive and highly competitive research efforts are made in the field of the development of coordination polymers (CPs) and in particular in the area of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). One of the most recent fascinating and fast growing subfields of the CPs’ research studies is related to the synthesis, characterization, and performance evaluation of energetic CPs and MOFs. In contrast to traditional energetic materials, energetic CPs can possess high thermal and chemical stabilities and relatively high detonation performance and exhibit broad range sensitivities to mechanical impact and friction, spanning properties of primary explosives to insensitive energetic materials. Energetic CPs have a significant potential to serve as components and catalysts in propellants and fuels, as well as in pyrotechnic formulations of colored smokes and flares, with a better color quality and intensity, releasing more environmentally friendly combustion products (vs presently used pyrotechnic compositions).

One of the most recent fascinating and fast growing subfields of the CPs' research studies is related to the synthesis, characterization, and performance evaluation of energetic CPs and MOFs. In contrast to traditional energetic materials, energetic CPs can possess high thermal and chemical stabilities and relatively high detonation performance and exhibit broad range sensitivities to mechanical impact and friction, spanning properties of primary explosives to insensitive energetic materials. Energetic CPs have a significant potential to serve as components and catalysts in propellants and fuels, as well as in pyrotechnic formulations of colored smokes and flares, with a better color quality and intensity, releasing more environmentally friendly combustion products (vs presently used pyrotechnic compositions).

elements.content: Frequently, nitrogen-rich heterocyclic ligands are used for preparation of energetic CPs. These ligands include 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole; 3-hydrazino-4-amino-1,2,4-triazole; 3-nitro-1H-1,2,4-triazole; 3-(1H-tetrazol-5-yl)-1H-triazole; 4,4′-azo-1,2,4-triazole; 4,4′-azo-1,2,4-triazol-5-one; 1H,1′H-5,5′-bitetrazole; 1,5-diamino-tetrazole; 5-methyl-tetrazole; 5-aminotetrazole; N,N′-bis­(1H-tetrazole-5-yl)-amine; 5-(1-methylhydrazinyl)-tetrazole; 5,5′-bistetrazole-1,1′-diolate; and others (). In the frame of our efforts to develop “greener” energetic materials, a versatile and multifunctional 1-amino-tetrazol-5-one (ATO) nitrogen-rich ligand () was synthesized and used to prepare new energetic CPs. In comparison with a closely related tetrazolone ligand (TO, ), the ATO molecule has an additional amino group in its structure, which increases nitrogen content from 65.1% (TO) to 69.3% (ATO). A higher nitrogen content is highly desirable for reduction of released smoke and particulate matter (as more nitrogen gas is formed during the combustion process), where the presence of amino groups was found contributing to improve thermostability of the ligand and the resulted CPs. More specifically, we selected alkaline (Li, Na, K, Rb, and Cs) and earth alkaline (Mg, Ca, Sr, and Ba) as coordination mental centers to coordinate with ATO ligand. All prepared CPs were comprehensively characterized by Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer, nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), mass spectrometry, elemental analysis, and X-ray crystallography. In order to evaluate our energetic CPs potential range of applications, we also studied their thermal properties and energy content [by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and bomb calorimetry], sensitivity to mechanical impact and friction, exposure to open flame, and calculated energetic performance (by using EXPLO5 v.6.04 software).

elements.content:
Caution! ATO and its CPs are energetic compounds and should be handled and stored properly, using protective gear, such as safety glasses, face shield, leather coat, earplugs, and thick gloves.

Synthesis and Analysis

ATO was synthesized for the first time in 1983 by Confalone and Woodward and more recently by our group. The ATO-derived energetic CPs were synthesized in high yields (85–95%) by reacting an aqueous suspension of ATO (1.01 g, 10 mmol) with alkaline or earth alkaline metal carbonates (5 mmol) at room temperature. After 1 h of stirring, the obtained clear solutions were treated under reduced pressure and the resulted solids were recrystallized from water by slow evaporation, giving crystals of pure CPs 1–7 and 9 that were suitable for X-ray crystallography ().

Experimental Section

 Caution! ATO and its CPs are energetic compounds and should be handled and stored properly, using protective gear, such as safety glasses, face shield, leather coat, earplugs, and thick gloves.

Synthesis and Analysis

ATO was synthesized for the first time in 1983 by Confalone and Woodward and more recently by our group. The ATO-derived energetic CPs were synthesized in high yields (85-95%) by reacting an aqueous suspension of ATO (1.01 g, 10 mmol) with alkaline or earth alkaline metal carbonates (5 mmol) at room temperature. After 1 h of stirring, the obtained clear solutions were treated under reduced pressure and the resulted solids were recrystallized from water by slow evaporation, giving crystals of pure CPs 1-7 and 9 that were suitable for X-ray crystallography ().

elements.content: The molecular structures of the prepared ATO complexes were comprehensively characterized. 13C NMR was recorded by using a 400 MHz NMR spectrometer (in DMSO-d 6). Mass spectra were measured on a liquid chromatography mass spectrometry machine equipped with an electrospray ionization ion source. IR spectra were recorded (KBr) on an FT-IR spectrometer. Elemental analysis was carried out using an elemental analyzer. More detailed information and spectral results are provided in the Supporting Information section.

Elemental analysis was carried out using an elemental analyzer. More detailed information and spectral results are provided in the Supporting Information section.

elements.content: The crystal structures were determined by X-ray crystallography measured at 293–298 K. The crystals were irradiated using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data collection and refinement were performed with Bruker SMART. The structures were solved with SHELXS-97 program and refined with SHELXL-97 program. Crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography of CPs 1–7 and 9 were obtained as mentioned before, while solid CP-8 was found to have a very low solubility in various solvents and was very problematic for crystallization. The summary of crystallographic data for CP-1 (CCDC-1018906), CP-2 (CCDC-1018897), CP-3 (CCDC-1018903), CP-4 (CCDC-1018909), CP-5 (CCDC-1875031), CP-6 (CCDC-1875188), CP-7 (CCDC-1875058), and CP-9 (CCDC-1018918) is provided in Table S1 (Supporting Information).

elements.content: The thermal behaviors of the prepared CPs were measured by DSC and TG analyses, which was performed under dry nitrogen atmosphere, with a flowing rate of 20 mL·min–1 and a linear heating rate of 5 °C·min–1. Typical samples of about 1 mg in ceramic crucibles were used. The impact sensitivity (IS) was determined by using a BAM fall hammer apparatus with 5 kg drop weight on 15 mg samples. The combustion flame was test by placing a few milligrams of a sample on a metal spatula to hold in the open flame of a Bunsen burner.

The combustion flame was test by placing a few milligrams of a sample on a metal spatula to hold in the open flame of a Bunsen burner.

elements.content: CP-1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2­(1)/n containing four molecules per unit cell. As shown in a, the Li cation is coordinated in a distorted tetrahedron by two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N2) from two different ATO ligands and two oxygen atoms (O1, O3) from one ATO ligand and one water molecule, respectively. The corresponding coordination bond lengths and bond angles are as follows: r(Li–N1) = 2.040 Å, r(Li–N2) = 2.113 Å, r(Li–O1) = 1.911 Å, r(Li–O2) = 1.958 Å, ∠N1–Li–N2 = 105.5°, ∠O1–Li–N2 = 108.4°, ∠O2–Li–N2 = 106.6°, ∠O1–Li–O2 = 111.8°, ∠O1–Li–N1 = 117.1°, ∠O2–Li–N1 = 106.8°. b shows the 1D chain of CP-1, in which adjacent Li metal centers are linked by bridging ATO ligand in one direction. The adjacent nonbonding Li···Li distance is 3.854 Å. The 1D structure is linked by five different hydrogen bonds, with distances ranging from 2.892 to 3.015 Å, to yield a stable 3D network structure (c).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Description

CP-1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2(1)/n containing four molecules per unit cell. As shown in a, the Li cation is coordinated in a distorted tetrahedron by two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N2) from two different ATO ligands and two oxygen atoms (O1, O3) from one ATO ligand and one water molecule, respectively. The corresponding coordination bond lengths and bond angles are as follows: r(Li-N1) = 2.040 Å, r(Li-N2) = 2.113 Å, r(Li-O1) = 1.911 Å, r(Li-O2) = 1.958 Å, ∠N1-Li-N2 = 105.5°, ∠O1-Li-N2 = 108.4°, ∠O2-Li-N2 = 106.6°, ∠O1-Li-O2 = 111.8°, ∠O1-Li-N1 = 117.1°, ∠O2-Li-N1 = 106.8°. b shows the 1D chain of CP-1, in which adjacent Li metal centers are linked by bridging ATO ligand in one direction. The adjacent nonbonding Li⋅⋅⋅Li distance is 3.854 Å. The 1D structure is linked by five different hydrogen bonds, with distances ranging from 2.892 to 3.015 Å, to yield a stable 3D network structure (c).

elements.content: CP-2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2­(1)/c with four molecules in the unit cell and a density of 1.701 g·cm–3. Each Na cation is hexa-coordinated by N1, O2, N3, O3 in the equatorial plane from two ATO ligands and one water molecule, and O1, O4 in the axial plane from another ATO ligand and water molecule, respectively (a). Bond lengths of Na–O and Na–N are in the range of 2.344–2.517 and 2.509–2.591 Å, respectively. ∠O–Na–O, ∠O–Na–N, and ∠N–Na–N deviate from either 90° or 180°, suggesting Na metal center bounds in a distorted octahedral coordination mode. The 2D network (b) was formed by two types of bridging modes: (1) Na cations bridged with O atoms of ATO ligand; (2) Na cations linked with one ATO molecule. The adjacent non-bonding Na···Na distances are 3.600 and 6.531 Å, respectively. Expanding the 2D sheets via hydrogen bonds (2.832–3.154 Å) yields a 3D structure (c).

The 2D network (b) was formed by two types of bridging modes: (1) Na cations bridged with O atoms of ATO ligand; (2) Na cations linked with one ATO molecule. The adjacent non-bonding Na⋅⋅⋅Na distances are 3.600 and 6.531 Å, respectively. Expanding the 2D sheets via hydrogen bonds (2.832-3.154 Å) yields a 3D structure (c).

elements.content: CP-3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2­(1)/c with eight molecules in the cell and a density of 2.067 g·cm–3. Each K cation is deca-coordinated by N, O, C atoms from six different ATO anions, and no metal-coordinated water molecules or noncoordinated water molecules were found in the crystal structure of CP-3 (a). The K metal center has a distorted polyhedral coordination geometry, with coordination angles deviating from 90° or 180°. The bond lengths of K–O are in the range of 2.768–2.907 Å, where K–N bonds have lengths in the range of 2.910–3.139 Å. b shows the 2D sheet of CP-3, in which the adjacent K cations are bridged by ATO ligands in two directions. The 2D sheets interact with each other forming a 3D framework through N–H···N hydrogen bonds (3.250–3.316 Å), which can be clearly seen in c.

elements.content: CP-4 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2­(1)/n with a density of 2.118 g·cm–3. As shown in a, Rb cation is deca-coordinated by five nitrogen atoms (N1, N2, N3, N5, and N5) from three ATO ligands, three oxygen atoms (O1, O3, and O4) from three water molecules, and one oxygen (O2) and one carbon (C1) atoms from another one ATO ligand. This type of coordination arrangement is unprecedented and forms a highly distorted polyhedron with r(Rb–O) = 2.876–3.188 Å, r(Rb–N) = 3.158–3.462 Å, r(Rb–C) = 3.695 Å, ∠O–Rb–O = 78.98°–137.84°, ∠O–Rb–N = 63.06°–154.60°, ∠N–Rb–N = 23.55°–135.12°, ∠O–Rb–C = 19.30°–124.28°, ∠N–Rb–C = 60.51°–158.13°. b shows the 2D layer, in which the adjacent Rb metal centers are linked by ATO ligand in two directions, to form a nearly square grid. The nonbonding Rb···Rb lengths are 4.129, 8.385, 7.822, and 10.655 Å, respectively. The adjacent layers are interacting with each other by hydrogen bond interactions, to yield a stable 3D supramolecular network (c).

elements.content: CP-5 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2­(1)/c with four molecules in the unit cell (ρ = 2.411 g·cm–3). As described in a, Cs cation is dodeca-coordinated by N1, C1, O1, N2, N3, N4, N5, O2, O3, O4, O5, and O6 from four ATO ligands and five H2O water molecules, respectively. The bond distances of Cs–O are ranging from 3.075 to 3.808 Å, and those of Cs–N are from 3.306 to 3.597 Å. All coordination angles deviate from 90° or 180°, showing a distorted polyhedral structure. In contrast to Li, Na, K, and Rb cations, in case of Cs cation, it can assemble with ATO ligands to form a 3D structure directly (b). Because of the relatively long bonds lengths of Cs–N and Cs–O, this compound is probably ionic. There also exists plenty of hydrogen bonds in the crystal structure of CP-5. For clarity, the hydrogen bonds are omitted in b.

elements.content: CP-6 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ with a density of 1.562 g·cm–3. As shown in a, each Mg cation is coordinated by six water molecules in distances of 2.063–2.111 Å, uncoordinated with ATO ligand. Because of its crystallographic structure, CP-6 could be classified as an ionic compound. The ∠O–Mg–O is almost 90° or 180°, suggesting the coordination mode is almost regular octahedral. Many hydrogen bonds result in formation of a 3D framework in the case of this compound (b). Notably, a large amount of coordinated water molecules in the crystal structure of CP-6 leads to its low solid-state density.

elements.content: CP-7 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ with two molecular units per cell and a density of 1.705 g·cm–3. The Ca cation is octa-coordinated by three N atoms (N1, N2, N3) and four O atoms (O1, O3, O4, O5) from five ATO ligands, and one O atom (O2) from one water molecule (a). Two ATO ligands adopt bidentate chelating mode and other three have monodentate mode. The adjacent Ca cations are linked by bridging O, N, and C atoms in ATO ligands to form a 1D chain (b). Abundant hydrogen bonds including O–H···N, N–H···N, and N–H···O linked the 1D chains to form a 3D network with an inclined “Z” shape (c).
elements.clean_text: CP-7 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ with two molecular units per cell and a density of 1.705 g⋅cm-3. The Ca cation is octa-coordinated by three N atoms (N1, N2, N3) and four O atoms (O1, O3, O4, O5) from five ATO ligands, and one O atom (O2) from one water molecule (a). Two ATO ligands adopt bidentate chelating mode and other three have monodentate mode. The adjacent Ca cations are linked by bridging O, N, and C atoms in ATO ligands to form a 1D chain (b). Abundant hydrogen bonds including O-H⋅⋅⋅N, N-H⋅⋅⋅N, and N-H⋅⋅⋅O linked the 1D chains to form a 3D network with an inclined "Z" shape (c).

elements.content: CP-9 crystallizes in the mono clinic space group C2/c with eight molecules in the unit cell and a density of 2.575 g·cm–3. As shown in a, the Ba cation is octa-coordinated by four ATO ligands (O1, O2, O4, N1, N2, O5) and two water molecules (O3, O6). Two ATO ligands adopt the bidentate chelating bridging modes and another two adopt the monodentate mode. The adjacent Ba cations are linked by three O atoms, two from ATO ligands, and one from one water molecule, to form a 1D chain (b). The adjacent nonbonding Ba···Ba distance is 4.470 Å. 1D chains are linked in three directions by two kinds of hydrogen bonds (O–H···N and N–H···N) to yield a 3D structure having a “multicycle” shape (c).

elements.content:
Lengths of hydrogen bonds in CPs 1–7 and 9 are listed in Table S2 (Supporting Information).

Thermal Properties

The thermal properties of CPs 1–9 were studied by DSC and TGA techniques, demonstrating that most of these CPs show exothermic behavior at elevated temperatures ().

For CP-1, the DSC curve shows two endothermic processes: one takes place at 125.1 °C (peak temperature), corresponding to the first weight loss stage, with 16% weight loss (121.6–127.7 °C in TGA curve), indicating a loss of a water molecule; the other process happens at 292.8 °C, accompanied by about 39.2% weight loss (280.3–295.9 °C in TGA curve). The TGA curve of CP-1 also shows another two weight loss stages, the first locates at 390.3–438.5 °C and the second at 587.9–612.9 °C, with weight losses of 20.6 and 7.4%, respectively.

elements.content: For CP-2, two endothermic and one exothermic processes were observed. The first process takes place around 80.5–97.5 °C, corresponding to 23.1% weight loss at 72.8–104.6 °C in TGA curve, in which stage two water molecules are lost. The second process occurs at 275 °C, with a weight loss of 19.1%, reflecting release of one N2 molecule in this stage. The third process happens at 285.4 °C, with loss weight of 13.0%. Above 420 °C, no further decomposition was observed.

elements.content: For CP-3, the DSC curve shows a single exothermic process at 236.5 °C, corresponding to a weight loss of 20.4% that at 238.7–269.1 °C in the TGA curve related to liberation of a molecule of N2. The TGA curve also shows another two weight loss stages at 324.2–363.8 and 729.1 °C, with total weight loss of 40.1%.

The TGA curve also shows another two weight loss stages at 324.2-363.8 and 729.1 °C, with total weight loss of 40.1%.

elements.content: For CP-4, no obvious endothermic and exothermic processes were detected. The small peak at 183.9 °C may imply that a phase transformation happens. The TGA curve shows three weight loss stages. The first stage is at 232.3–271.3 °C, lost 11.9% weight to give off one molecule of water. The second one is at 326.6–369.2 °C, with a weight loss of 12.2%, related to emit one N2 molecule. The third process is at 500–800 °C, with a weight loss of 33.8%.

The second and third stages happen at 328.5–373.2 and 622.8–706.3 °C, with weight losses of 12.0 and 10.3%, respectively, related to loss of two N2 molecules.

elements.content: For CP-6, the DSC curve exhibits a strong endothermal process at 94.2 °C, corresponding to the weight loss of 30.0% at 82.4–98.4 °C in the TGA curve, indicating a loss of six water molecules in this process. The DSC curve also shows a wide exothermal process at 278.5 °C, corresponding to the weight loss of 33.4% at 259.5–300.9 °C to release four molecules of N2. Another weight loss stage takes place at 500.0–660.2 °C, with a weight loss of 13.4%.

elements.content: For CP-7, the DSC curve shows complex decomposition process. The first endothermic peak was found at 69.7 °C, with a weight loss of 4.6%. The second peak was detected at 152.9 °C, with a weight loss of 8.7%. These two stages together most probably correspond to loss of two molecules of water, indicating a stepwise dehydration of CP-7. The clear exothermal peak at 281.5 °C, with a weight loss of 29.1%, related to release of three N2 molecules. In addition, a mild weight loss of 30.1% at 350–680 °C could be observed in the TGA curve.

elements.content: DSC data show that use of the ATO ligand leads to formation of CPs with higher thermostability than of the similar CPs containing the TO ligand. The emitted substances during TG analyses were proposed based on the weight loss ratios, and the calculation details are listed in Table S3 (Supporting Information).

elements.content: The constant-volume heat of combustion (Q v) was measured by bomb calorimetry, and the constant-pressure heat of combustion (Q p) was obtained on a basis of the formula Q p = Q v + ΔnRT. Then, the heat of formation (ΔH f) at 298 K was calculated according to the combustion – and the Hess thermochemical cycle. We found that CP-7 possesses the highest Q p (−1783.3 kJ·mol–1), whereas CP-3 possesses the lowest Q p (−710 kJ·mol–1). All CPs exhibit negative ΔH f, ranging from −150.9 to −2017.6 kJ·mol–1 (). Detonation velocity (D) and detonation pressure (P) were calculated with EXPLO5 software. D and P values for our CPs were found to be in ranges between 6.83 and 8.11 km·s–1 and between 16.53 and 24.51 GPa, respectively (). D and P values for CP-4 and CP-5 could not be calculated because of the limitations of the EXPLO5 software. The density (ρ) of CP-8 was not obtained because of the lack of its X-ray crystallography data. Energy Content, Sensitivity, and Color of Flame Tests

The constant-volume heat of combustion (Q v) was measured by bomb calorimetry, and the constant-pressure heat of combustion (Q p) was obtained on a basis of the formula Q p = Q v + ΔnRT. Then, the heat of formation (ΔH f) at 298 K was calculated according to the combustion - and the Hess thermochemical cycle. We found that CP-7 possesses the highest Q p (-1783.3 kJ⋅mol-1), whereas CP-3 possesses the lowest Q p (-710 kJ⋅mol-1). All CPs exhibit negative ΔH f, ranging from -150.9 to -2017.6 kJ⋅mol-1 (). Detonation velocity (D) and detonation pressure (P) were calculated with EXPLO5 software. D and P values for our CPs were found to be in ranges between 6.83 and 8.11 km⋅s-1 and between 16.53 and 24.51 GPa, respectively (). D and P values for CP-4 and CP-5 could not be calculated because of the limitations of the EXPLO5 software. IS of all CPs was determined on a standard BAM fall hammer apparatus, with 5 kg dropping weight, using 15 mg samples. Friction sensitivity (FS) of all CPs was determined on standard BAM friction apparatus. Most of our energetic CPs can be considered as insensitive to impact and friction, with values higher than 40 J and 360 N, respectively, except for CP-3, which exhibited a low IS (IS = 36 J) (). In addition, all CPs were evaluated with “color of flame” test, producing characteristic colors of emission ().

cln_elements.content:
In our effort to seek for the “green” energetic coordination polymers (CPs), a versatile and multifunctional 1-amino-tetrazol-5-one ligand was synthesized and its complexes with a series of alkaline and earth alkaline metals were prepared and comprehensively characterized. A broad range of differently shaped 1D, 2D, and 3D supramolecular structures for the prepared energetic compounds were found, where each metal was bound in a specific and characteristic fashion. All prepared CPs show very good thermostability, with decomposition temperatures above 236 °C and remarkable insensitivity to mechanical impact and friction (impact sensitivity > 40 J, friction sensitivity > 360 N). In terms of detonation performance, our CPs were calculated to have detonation velocities in the range of 6.8–8.1 km·s–1 and detonation pressures in the range of 16.5–24.5 GPa. Upon their combustion, new materials show a range of characteristic flame colors (from yellow to blue), making these compounds as promising components for various “green” pyrotechnic formulations.

CP-3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2­(1)/c with eight molecules in the cell and a density of 2.067 g·cm–3. Each K cation is deca-coordinated by N, O, C atoms from six different ATO anions, and no metal-coordinated water molecules or noncoordinated water molecules were found in the crystal structure of CP-3 (a). The K metal center has a distorted polyhedral coordination geometry, with coordination angles deviating from 90° or 180°. The bond lengths of K–O are in the range of 2.768–2.907 Å, where K–N bonds have lengths in the range of 2.910–3.139 Å. b shows the 2D sheet of CP-3, in which the adjacent K cations are bridged by ATO ligands in two directions. The 2D sheets interact with each other forming a 3D framework through N–H···N hydrogen bonds (3.250–3.316 Å), which can be clearly seen in c.

CP-6 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ with a density of 1.562 g·cm–3. As shown in a, each Mg cation is coordinated by six water molecules in distances of 2.063–2.111 Å, uncoordinated with ATO ligand. Because of its crystallographic structure, CP-6 could be classified as an ionic compound. The ∠O–Mg–O is almost 90° or 180°, suggesting the coordination mode is almost regular octahedral. Many hydrogen bonds result in formation of a 3D framework in the case of this compound (b). Notably, a large amount of coordinated water molecules in the crystal structure of CP-6 leads to its low solid-state density.

Lengths of hydrogen bonds in CPs 1–7 and 9 are listed in Table S2 (Supporting Information).

Thermal Properties

The thermal properties of CPs 1–9 were studied by DSC and TGA techniques, demonstrating that most of these CPs show exothermic behavior at elevated temperatures ().

For CP-1, the DSC curve shows two endothermic processes: one takes place at 125.1 °C (peak temperature), corresponding to the first weight loss stage, with 16% weight loss (121.6–127.7 °C in TGA curve), indicating a loss of a water molecule; the other process happens at 292.8 °C, accompanied by about 39.2% weight loss (280.3–295.9 °C in TGA curve). The TGA curve of CP-1 also shows another two weight loss stages, the first locates at 390.3–438.5 °C and the second at 587.9–612.9 °C, with weight losses of 20.6 and 7.4%, respectively.

For CP-2, two endothermic and one exothermic processes were observed. The first process takes place around 80.5–97.5 °C, corresponding to 23.1% weight loss at 72.8–104.6 °C in TGA curve, in which stage two water molecules are lost. The second process occurs at 275 °C, with a weight loss of 19.1%, reflecting release of one N2 molecule in this stage. The third process happens at 285.4 °C, with loss weight of 13.0%. Above 420 °C, no further decomposition was observed.

For CP-3, the DSC curve shows a single exothermic process at 236.5 °C, corresponding to a weight loss of 20.4% that at 238.7–269.1 °C in the TGA curve related to liberation of a molecule of N2. The TGA curve also shows another two weight loss stages at 324.2–363.8 and 729.1 °C, with total weight loss of 40.1%.

For CP-4, no obvious endothermic and exothermic processes were detected. The small peak at 183.9 °C may imply that a phase transformation happens. The TGA curve shows three weight loss stages. The first stage is at 232.3–271.3 °C, lost 11.9% weight to give off one molecule of water. The second one is at 326.6–369.2 °C, with a weight loss of 12.2%, related to emit one N2 molecule. The third process is at 500–800 °C, with a weight loss of 33.8%.

For CP-5, the DSC curve shows three endothermal processes at 66.1, 97.1, and 136.9 °C. The TGA curve shows three weight loss processes. The first one takes place at 229–265.8 °C, with weight loss of 11.4%, corresponding to loss of two water molecules. The second and third stages happen at 328.5–373.2 and 622.8–706.3 °C, with weight losses of 12.0 and 10.3%, respectively, related to loss of two N2 molecules.

For CP-6, the DSC curve exhibits a strong endothermal process at 94.2 °C, corresponding to the weight loss of 30.0% at 82.4–98.4 °C in the TGA curve, indicating a loss of six water molecules in this process. The DSC curve also shows a wide exothermal process at 278.5 °C, corresponding to the weight loss of 33.4% at 259.5–300.9 °C to release four molecules of N2. Another weight loss stage takes place at 500.0–660.2 °C, with a weight loss of 13.4%.

For CP-7, the DSC curve shows complex decomposition process. The first endothermic peak was found at 69.7 °C, with a weight loss of 4.6%. The second peak was detected at 152.9 °C, with a weight loss of 8.7%. These two stages together most probably correspond to loss of two molecules of water, indicating a stepwise dehydration of CP-7. The clear exothermal peak at 281.5 °C, with a weight loss of 29.1%, related to release of three N2 molecules. In addition, a mild weight loss of 30.1% at 350–680 °C could be observed in the TGA curve.

For CP-8, the DSC curve shows two endothermal and one exothermal processes. The first endothermal process is at 187.5 °C, with a weight loss of 13.4%, lost two water molecules. The following process takes place at 282.4 °C, with 26.1% weight loss, which corresponds to releasing of three molecules of N2. The final exothermal process takes place at 410.3 °C, with a weight loss of 19.6%.

For CP-9, DSC shows two endothermal processes. One process takes place at 191.8 °C, with a weight loss of 5.0%, corresponding to a loss of one water molecule. The following process happens at 269.4 °C, with a weight loss of 22.1%, which most probably indicate the loss of three N2 molecules. The third process (372.5 °C) is exothermic, with a weight loss of 15.8%, that could be attributed to the loss of two N2 molecules. In the TGA curve, there is another weight loss of 2.7%.

Conclusions

In summary, nine energetic CPs and ionic compounds were synthesized based on the nitrogen-rich ligand ATO and their structures were fully characterized by NMR, FT-IR, mass spectrometry, elemental analysis, and X-ray crystallography. The new materials’ densities are ranging from 1.602 to 2.575 g·cm–3, and they show energetic properties characteristic to pyrotechnics and have excellent thermostability and insensitivity to mechanical impact and friction. Each of these compounds would also exhibit a characteristic flame color, making them promising components for integration into perchlorate-free “green” pyrotechnics. Not less important is the unprecedented capability of the ATO ligand to bind various alkaline and earth alkaline metal ions in a unique mode, forming metal-specific CPs and ionic compounds with completely different structures.
